The October FOMC statement came across as hawkish and points to a December meeting that is clearly in play. Beyond a modest acknowledgement of slowing in the pace of job gains, the assessment of the domestic economy was generally consistent or decidedly upgraded from September.

Critically, the Fed also dropped the line on the potential for global developments to put downward pressure on domestic inflation, and referred explicitly to its "next meeting" in discussing "whether it will be appropriate to raise" rates. With recent developments from the ECB, followed this week by the Fed, the divergence theme is very much alive.

At a macro level, this introduces a range of complicated dynamics, with the obvious tension that we think the EUR front end is cheap for what we believe the ECB is trying to achieve and the USD front end expensive for the Fed's intentions. For the FX market, the read-across to a stronger dollar is straightforward, but for rates, the speed of that move could quickly end up complicating the market's response to new data. We seek to reflect that in our trade recommendations.

A more hawkish October FOMC statement led to a reset in rates and a rise in the USD, while US equities recovered to close up 1%, at the highs. The market-implied probability of a December hike jumped over 10pp, to 46%, the level prior to the dovish September statement. The US 2y rose 8bp and the curve flattened. The euro fell over 1% on the news and EM equities fell over 2% peak to trough intraday, recovering some losses as equities bounced. Financials and small cap stocks led the equity move, while oil and oil-linked assets rallied on positive inventory news.

Our economists see the statement as an active effort to leave the door open to December (Full Story). In the largest surprise, the sentence on global risks was removed, indicating to us a desire to send a hawkish signal. We believe actions by the PBOC and ECB have eased the FOMC’s concerns about risks from abroad. Additionally, the Fed strengthened its timing language, stating “in determining whether it will be appropriate to raise the target range at its next meeting…”. Despite the hawkish tone, we believe that soft inflation data and ongoing turbulence in emerging markets will keep the Fed on hold until March 2016.

Although we didn't think the Fed would take a December hike off the table, it
was a surprise for them to warn the market so explicitly that a rate rise was a
distinct possibility at their next meeting. A key line was the first part of the
following sentence which was added this month - “In determining whether it
will be appropriate to raise the target range at its next meeting, the Committee
will assess progress--both realized and expected--toward its objectives of
maximum employment and 2 percent inflation.” They also removed the
following sentence that was in the September statement: “Recent global
economic and financial developments may restrain economic activity
somewhat and are likely to put further downward pressure on inflation in the
near term.” So the Fed think financial conditions have calmed enough for them
to try to prepare markets for their long desired hike. Whether this eventually
causes the same cycle of risk-off again is the big question. It didn't last night
as the S&P closed +1.18%, having fallen -1% post statement before rallying all
the way back at the close.

11:13 am
BE

Other parts of the statement didn't really acknowledge recent weaker data.
The Fed continues to see growth "expanding at a moderate pace" in spite of
Q3 GDP estimated by most economists to have a 1-handle. They also said “Household and business fixed investment have been increasing at solid rates.” even though the latest retail sales or durable goods data both missed. Retail sales ex auto and gas was 0.0% mom in September missing expectations by three-tenths (and the lowest monthly reading since April) while the latest durable goods ex transportation data printed at -0.4% mom, a miss versus expectations by four-tenths and the second consecutive negative monthly print. Meanwhile with regards to employment the Fed’s assessment was downgraded, with “solid job gains” replaced with “The pace of job gains slowed.” which is appropriate given the last payroll print. Reading between the lines the old 200k unofficial payroll target for a hike may have been lowered.

BE

Overall the criteria for whether they hike in December continues to be data and financial market dependant but they have given the market warning of where their biases lie. All year we've been pretty convinced they won't hike in 2015 but last night's statement definitely puts us at risk of being wrong at the final hurdle. The probability of a December hike has now bumped up to 46% from around 35% 24 hours ago after having been as low as 26% earlier this month. Unsurprisingly it was a strong day for the USD with the Dollar index up +0.90% while US Treasury yields climbed higher. The 10y finished the day up +6.4bps at 2.102% while at the shorter end of the curve 2y yields were up +8.2bps (to 0.705%) for the biggest daily move higher since March 6th. Some of those moves were also supported by the September advance goods trade balance reading yesterday, with the deficit shrinking to $58.6bn from $66.6bn last month and to a seven-month low after exports rose +3.1% in the month and imports declined -2.5%.

■ Expectations on an inversion have increased. Recent commentary by

BE

AGN one of the few targets that fit PFE's inversion aspirations. Given
PFE's size, there are few targets they could pursue for an inversion. Of the
potential targets, we still believe AZN would be the best fit from a strategic
and financial perspective, although that may be difficult to execute following
last year's failed pursuit of the company. GSK is another company that is
commonly mentioned, but we would not be big fans given the more limited
positive impact that deal would have on both PFE's innovative and
established business, in our opinion. This leaves AGN, which we think
would add needed near-term growth and a modest pipeline to PFE
innovative business but, ironically, less to PFE's GEP business given AGN
has recently sold off much of the old Actavis business to TEVA.

BE

■ Reasonable premium on equity-based deal would meet 60/40 threshold. Given
last year's US Treasury proposal around tax inversions, the split in equity between the
buyer and target is important to monitor. Looking simply at the current market cap of
the two companies ($218Bn for PFE and $113Bn for AGN); PFE's market cap is about
65% of the combined market cap for the two companies. Again, without details on how
a deal would be structured, it is tough to assess how the combined entity would look
but it does appear like PFE could reach the 60/40 equity split threshold by consuming a
deal with a reasonable premium should it be a heavily equity-based. We believe the
possibility also exists of a creative deal being consumed with AGN actually being the
one acquiring PFE, which could then avoid many of the issues of trying to complete a
high-profile inversion.

BE

And JP Morgan

BE

we see a combination
with Allergan 1) accelerating Pfizer’s innovative growth profile, 2) generating
meaningful operating synergies, 3) likely allowing Pfizer to invert, and 4) potentially
driving significant accretion. In addition, we see a combination with Allergan
strengthening Pfizer's innovative business and creating a more compelling case for a
break-up of the larger Pfizer organization.

BE

 We see an Allergan deal accelerating Pfizer’s growth profile. We note that
Pfizer’s business development efforts have been focused on growth assets that could
immediately contribute to the innovative business, helping to bridge between the
current launches and several longer-term opportunities. With several new launch
products (Viberzi, Kybella, Vraylar), and continued double-digit growth from
several key products (Botox, Linzess, Restasis, dermal fillers, etc.), we see an
Allergan acquisition being growth-accretive to Pfizer's innovative business as well
as the broader company. For reference, we are forecasting 9% top-line growth in
2016-2020 for Allergan, 3% growth for Pfizer's innovative business, and 2% growth
for the broader Pfizer organization.

BE

 Such a deal would likely generate meaningful operating synergies. Given the
significant primary care infrastructures in both organizations, we see the potential
for meaningful operating synergies. In addition, we see overlap in several
therapeutic categories, including CNS (Namenda, Viibryd), Women’s Health, and
Cardiovascular (Bystolic), among others. Assuming synergies in-line with recent
pharma mergers, we estimate that a Pfizer/Allergan combination could drive $2bn of
operating synergies over time.

11:21 am
BE

 In addition, an Allergan acquisition could allow Pfizer to invert. Pfizer’s
management on this week's earning call commented that they remain open to
potential inversion transactions, and we believe an Allergan acquisition would likely
allow Pfizer to re-domicile. While discussions appear at an early stage based on
media reports, we note that such a deal could potentially be structured as either a
40% inversion (where Allergan would represent at least 40% of the combined
company’s equity) or a 20% inversion (Allergan 20-40% of the pro-forma
company). Although a 40% inversion would grant greater tax benefits, a 20%
inversion would leave Allergan's existing cash and cash flow unencumbered and
could drive some beneficial tax treatment to Pfizer's existing cash and cash flow on a
situational basis.

BE

 While a deal structure has yet to be proposed, we see such a combination
potentially driving significant accretion. While a deal structure has yet to be
proposed, we believe a Pfizer/Allergan combination could generate meaningful
accretion. Assuming a 20% inversion with a 60/40 cash/stock deal at $375-$400/ AGN
share (in-line with historical inversion premiums), $2bn of operating synergies (in-line
with historical pharma mergers), and a blended tax rate, we calculate that an acquisition
could drive high-single-digit to low-double-digit accretion.
 A combination with Allergan would strengthen the innovative business's profile,
setting up a longer-term break-up, in our view. In our view, an acquisition of
Allergan would bolster the growth profile of Pfizer's innovative business, strengthening
the innovative business’s status as a top-tier biopharma. With the recently closed
Hospira acquisition (which added to the established business’s growth profile), we see
two well-positioned stand-alone business units. We note that our previous sum-of-theparts
work continues to suggest upside to Pfizer’s valuation (to the low-mid $40s) as we
consider the growth and strategic potential of the company’s various businesses.
 Given what is likely a significant equity component, management structure
remains a question. Given what would likely be a significant equity component in a
~$150bn+ deal, we assume Allergan management would likely want a significant role in
the combined company. As such, the potential management structure of the combined
company remains in question. We believe combined management team comprising
leaders from both organizations (similar to prior AGN transactions) would minimize
integration risk.

GSK being increasingly viewed as an outside bet, or hedge against AGN: Recent
media speculation as well as yesterday’s Q3’15 earnings call for GlaxoSmithKline has shifted
investor focus toward the potential of Pfizer bidding for it as an alternative inversion
candidate to Allergan. We give our thoughts on how a more typical bid premium compares
to "over-paying" to achieve a 60:40 inversion.
GSK often passed over by investors in favour of AGN: We often hear that an
acquisition of GlaxoSmithKline would be taken badly by investors, who generally view it as
a lower quality company, with a stretched dividend policy and poor R&D track record. In
addition, the politics (both with management and UK politicians) of achieving what would
need to be a "friendly" deal appears to be more challenging when compared to Allergan.
GSK may carry more synergies than expected: GlaxoSmithKline may have more
operational synergy with Pfizer than investors perceive given the complementary overlaps
in Vaccines, Consumer/OTC, GEP and ViiV. The two companies also have complementary
branded pharma businesses and it may be that GlaxoSmithKline's R&D update next week
shows more promise on innovation than investors currently perceive. On the politics point,
we believe that the GlaxoSmithKline board will consider any offer that is the right deal for
shareholders. Whilst UK politicians may not like the idea of a takeover by Pfizer, there may
be little they can do to prevent it.

BE

30% premium (£18.43) creates an attractive pro forma: We have created two
merger accretion models for this note, the first (Exhibit 1) addresses what we consider to
be a more "typical" bid premium of up to 30% (all-share) for GlaxoSmithKline, equating
to £18.43 at the time of writing. Whilst the assumptions behind this are laid out in detail,
the key point would be that we assume a higher tax rate for at least 10 years due to the
c38% stake that GlaxoSmithKline shareholders would have in the pro forma company. In
turn we assume that post-close share repurchases to enhance accretion would take place at
a relatively slow pace of $10bn per annum over 5 years. As a result, we see the deal being
"neutral" in 2016E (if closed mid-16) and up to 24.7% accretive to EPS on a pro forma basis
by 2020E (31.3% accretive by 2025E).
45% premium (£20.56) may be the magic number: An alternative analysis (Exhibit
2), where Pfizer pays a higher premium (45%, or £20.56 per share) to achieve a 60:40 "full
inversion" may be more attractive given the lower tax rate from day 1, immediate access
to Pfizer's offshore cash/cash flow and reduced risk of further Treasury Notices that could
further degrade the transaction. Using the same revenue and cost synergies as in the prior
example, but a lower tax rate (20% vs 22%-23%) and a more rapid share repurchase rate
(total of $50bn, but over two years) achieves a comparable result for Pfizer (23.9% EPS
accretion in 2020E; 30.0% by 2025E), but with more certainty of execution and flexibility
for use of cash. It is also a more enticing deal for GlaxoSmithKline with a higher take out
price, more certainty, faster share repurchase by Pfizer and comparable pro forma EPS.

11:27 am

the tax code. Either way, we still think we see an inversion, or a split, or tax reform (or a
combination of these) over the next 2-3 years, generating substantial upside for Pfizer.

BE

Chinese iron ore imports, resilient to date, are on the cusp of turning negative as its steel industry grapples with unsustainable margins and leverage. With rationalisation seemingly on the horizon, the next leg down in iron ore prices also looks imminent. The earnings impact to BHP and Rio of our $40/t forecast in 2016 can only be offset by moves in copper, oil and aluminium at the extremities of consensus or beyond. We downgrade BHP and Rio from HOLD to SELL, with price targets of £9 and £19.

BE

SinoSteel the trigger?
SinoSteel’s default on a $315m coupon could be the trigger for much needed rationalisation of the Chinese steel industry. Implied margins have now deteriorated to deeply unprofitable levels (c.$65/t) and leverage is unsustainable; four of the seven largest mills have ND/EBITDA over 5x. In addition, global political pressure is mounting to stop China dumping steel as domestic producers go bust (Tata in the UK).

BE

S/D balance deteriorating
We have re-run our supply model and despite reducing our supply estimates from Vale, Roy Hill and Sino Iron, we still have an incremental 86mt hitting the market in 2016. Meanwhile, on the demand side, Chinese property inventory continues to build up in absolute terms and developer leverage ratios are hitting new highs.
